comments.commentBody:
If intelligence officials knew about this hacking in late 2015, it is a shame that the White House wasn't informed sooner and the Russian government not informed that there would be serious consequences if the activity did not cease-- with follow-up action to deter the Russians if need be.

Another query: are campaign organizations and U.S. political parties also backing social media disinformation campaigns to influence elections? I would be surprised if some of this has not been occurring.

You assume the White House wasn't informed about what intelligence officials knew?

With all due respect, this could only be due to White House incompetence, or
is a figment of your imagination.

What can we expect from someone who has a record of swindling small contractors, a record of fraud and using plagiarized texts in his fake university, a record of using his charity for his own benefit, and a record of cheating investors in his ventures?

Today's WSJ head line, "Trump Creditors Are Many, Varied. "Trump business debt are held by more than 150 institutions. Hundreds of millions of debt attached to Trumps properties some backed by his personal grantee have been securitized, which has been used for more than $1 billion of debt connected to his properties.

Any default would put his whole enterprise into conflict with the lender, on of whom is Wells Fargo that Trump has the power to appoint its regulator.
With a little luck we will get the opportunity to watch him squirm and try to evade scrutiny for his "deals."

If you have not seen the Frontline PBS show on him, and hi personality, it revel just what kind of personality he is. He never admit a mistake, when called on them he sues, he attacks as we have seen with his personal attacks on his critics and accusers, and he seeks revenge.

We see his treatment of ambassadors as particularly hateful, people who have served Honorably, treated like some kind of enemy, this is the mark of a dictatorial Fascist. He even call the opposition his enemy. Ethics be damned, he is a sociopath, no conscience, a rotten to the core egomaniac.

If CIA can’t even “maximally-demote” Jason Bourne after 14 years “off the grid”, how much respect do you suppose the rest of us owe them?

I’m reminded of my gem on the importance of the press to a free and healthy society – but, then, the manufacturers of prophylactics could be said to contribute as much. CIA’s problem, as with the press, is the single-minded focus on its own importance as the lynchpin to Life, the Universe and Everything.

Let’s cut the kindergarten-nonsense. The leadership of our intelligence services, become RATHER politicized over the past eight years, set out to attack and damage Trump. And failed. So now it’s all umbrage and befuddlement at how he could be questioning the effectiveness of their efforts. The same efforts that concluded by global consensus that Saddam was awash in WMD – even fifteen years ago.

Trump doesn’t need CIA to tell him that Iran is ignoring its “accord” commitments: he knows they are (IAEA is telling him), which is why it may have another three months of life before it gets drop-kicked into the Persian Gulf.

Humor at this self-involvement aside, we all know about that wall at Langley covered by nameless stars, and we all have immense respect and gratitude for CIA and the dedication of its members – as, I’m sure, does Trump as well. But he’s under political attack, and whether or not CIA accepts it they’re abetting those attacks. But soon it will be TRUMP’S CIA and not Obama’s, and we can finally get beyond all this.

You have got to be kidding.  As it is apparent that you voted for Trump, you have no ability to judge character and temperament.  It is only a matter of time before the damage done by this narcissistic, impulsive, self- aggrandizing dangerous man will be too much even for the GOP-led Congress to take and he will be removed from office.  Only then will we actually begin to get beyond all this and begin to repair the damage.  I shudder and fear for the country and the world in the meantime.
Richard your comments used to be interesting when they contained some semblance of fact.

Once again, Richard, you cherry pick intelligence data to bolster your skewed interpretation of the facts. Like Trump, YOU are the one who has politicized facts to suit your ideology. That, dear contributor, is right out of the right-wing, GOP operating handbook.
And you're smug....ugh

A crazy person with a gun is bad enough. A crazy person with an army is even worse. Did anybody who voted for this loose cannon think this through? He was extremely defensive about his short fingers, but he's apparently all for small arms.

A silly tweet-happy buffoon is joining forces with gun nuts while making second-amendment jokes. Apparently he forgot that Sarah Palin's Facebook page put crosshairs on legislators who were pro-Obamacare, including Gabrielle Giffords. "Don't Retreat-Instead, RELOAD!" was the caption. Shortly thereafter, a crazy guy with a gun shot her in the head and killed six people in the process.

Maybe the Second Amendment is nothing to joke about.

All Democrats have been asking for were background checks to prevent known crazies from getting weapons. But frankly, background checks are unreliable. Case in point: no one's background demonstrated dishonesty, a history of sexual assault, a serious intellectual deficit and an almost-certain diagnosis of narcissistic personality disorder more than our president-defect, but that wasn't enough to disqualify him from a job where he could get his hands on nuclear weapons.

Face it, America. We shot ourselves in the foot when we elected this guy. We're supposed to hope that he'll become more measured in office. But when asked what he will do when he becomes president, he replies with one word: reload.

Well, the SCOTUS bears some responsibility in the demise  and deterioration of this, namely our, democratic Republic which now has become more or less an oligarchy. The obvious result is the election of, as you mentioned, president defect Trump.
Funny, I didn't see a single babushka at my polling place November 8. Must have been in the back hacking the voting machines. You know, the ones not connected to the internet.
Upstate: Agreed. But the SCOTUS was carefully packed by the GOP, and the Court reflects society. A great swathe of America is delusional and completely at odds with the spirit of the Constitution.

@Dan

Well it missed 9/11 and also the end of the Soviet Union - that very week it warned Reagan that the Soviet Union was getting stronger.

If you want a non flag waving view of the CIA read "Legacy of Ashes" by Tim Weiner and also the review of that book on the CIA webpage. BTW the title comes from President Eisenhower, who bemoaning his failure to reform the CIA said he was turning over to JFK a legacy of ashes (referring to the CIA). JFK learned the truth when the CIA ran the Bay of Pigs operation.
Three university professors of psychology have written to President Obama to ask for such testing by an impartial group of experts.
also quick solve. liked the number clue for sedate and convertible for sofa bed.

@Dan

If you want to get the flavor of the book here is the NY Times review with a long list of world shaking events that the CIA missed.

http://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/22/books/review/Thomas-t.html

Typical Luettgen evading of the issue.
I is not if Trump's appointees are self made billionaires, they are not. It is not a liberal conservative issue, it is a matter of what the law is.

The law is one that requires disclosure of conflicting interests, and divestiture of them before assuming the position. Are they honest or dishonest, are they deliberately avoiding complying with the law, are they being enabled to do so, by the GOP legislators?

RL just cant stick to the facts, it is his MO to try and confuse the issue. We al know his animus toward liberals and anyone who does not worship Il Duce. Twist the facts, confuse the issue, oh follower of Nietzsche, al the worlds problems can be solved by a few authoritarians, so says RL.

I just came back from Spain where they are still celebrating the end of one of these strong men,nor much different than Trump. This is a sad era in our history,he would have been despised all our previous presidents.

Many years ago I had two very early miscarriages that I mistook at the time for late and painful periods.  I did not realize what they really were until after my son was born.  I am able to look at them as nothing much, just happenstances that enabled me to have the two children I later conceived--I'd never have had more than two.  But new technology recognizes pregnancies so much earlier now.  I'm sure I'd have wanted a way to grieve those first two little ones had I known them to be such.

Looking at production and nonsupervisory employees shows less robust wage growth which has been stuck at 2.5% yoy since December 2015:

https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/fredgraph.png?g=cir9

That the average hourly earnings of all private employees is rising faster at now 2.9% yoy implies rising inequality of labor income.

Also, after-tax corporate profits still take an unusually high share of GDP even after falling from a recent record high of 10% in Q4 2011. As of Q3 2016 profits are still taking in large 8.4% share of the economy, which is well above the historical norms as can be seen here;

https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/fredgraph.png?g=ciAX

The point here is that wages can still rise a lot from here without threatening rising inflation. It's normal for the profits share to rise during the early stages of recovery from recession but then decline in the later stages of an expansion. That pattern is clear from the chart above.

Russia hacked the DNC and selected Democratic operatives, then embarrassingly WikiShafted them, largely to damage Hillary Clinton's election chances. But really to damage Hillary Clinton. Yet, if you're going to call Putin a "Nazi", something not usually heard from a U.S. Sec. of State at the time (does she even understand the devastation the Nazis wreaked in Russia?), then you MIGHT just expect some blowback.

So, don't get angry ... get even. And not by kicking out a few third-rate spooks and shutting down a couple of bordellos.

So, can we finally get beyond this? We're going to be just astonished at how all this outrage diminishes after 20 January, when CIA is no linger Obama's (who blew it by doing nothing about the hacking as it was happening) but Trump's. If it had been Trump's CIA months ago, we'd probably have fed Putin "fake news" in the hack about what a great buy Republic Airways was; and by now Putin would be broke.

paul - Hmmm, a thousand pardons, sir; we were indeed less than precise in this little Fri. eve post, and should have been scrupulous in our verbiage, instead saying " As Dr. K. reminds, this part of the economic cycle is not when Keynes would advocate deficit spending ".

Hopefully all confusion is now allayed :)

Raising taxes to achieve better economic results is another discussion.

Gail left out one bit. Lots of people will react to this by going out and buying another or a more powerful gun or guns and ammunition. Evan Osnos did some interesting research on how the NRA and guns marketers discovered they could manufacture a change in attitude, an increase in fear, to sell more guns.

"Making a Killing: The business and politics of selling guns" http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/06/27/after-orlando-examining-the...

Trump, whose main skill is marketing, would of course catch on to how he could enhance his sales pitch this way, along with the NRA support.

This desire to be able to kill people easily seems mad to me. Yet any time anyone says, a dead person is dead, their rights have been finally and comprehensively removed, those who want to be able to cause that finality with ease and without reserve tell us we're treading on their toes.

What about the finality of death is invisible to people? What about the humanity of other people is hidden from them?

Lots of otherwise decent people seem to lose their minds when it comes to guns. There is vast evidence that the presence of a casually stored gun in the home or elsewhere is much more likely to result in innocents being killed than anything else.

All my life I've been able to walk around without thinking about other people's guns. But there are people who feel I should be forced to arm myself. Why would I want to look at other people with suspicion and fear?

Let me be humane!

I, too, used to walk around innocently, perfectly happy in my state of non-aggression. But i live in FL. In a county that voted 65% for Trump. Where an old man killed a guy for texting in a movie theater that I attend. I absolutely will not buy/carry a gun. But I am much more aware of my surroundings, the general atmosphere. I drive very defensively, not only to avoid an accident but so I don't provoke road-rage also. So much for my innocent way of life.

Trump loves to market products in his name. A Trump gun anyone?

I am sorry to give Trump any more ideas. We hold the possession of a gun so lightly. But this has been building for a long time especially with our glorification of violence. The Top Gun has become our motto.

@Bewrnard Edmonds

What are you some kind of a nut - I don't want any crank mail, but you must love the attention (if you are using your real name.

The following is excerpted from the NY Times review of Legacy of Ashes:

When Henry Kissinger traveled to China in 1971, Prime Minister Chou En-lai asked about C.I.A subversion. Kissinger told Chou that he vastly overestimates the competence of the C.I.A"

The C.I.A. never did have much luck operating inside Communist China, and it failed to predict the Iranian revolution of 1979. The agency also did not foresee the

explosion of an atom bomb by the Soviet Union in 1949, the invasion of South
Korea in 1950, the popular uprisings in Eastern Europe in the 1950s, the installation of Soviet missiles in Cuba in 1962, the Arab-Israeli war of 1973, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979, the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1989, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, the explosion of an atom bomb by India in 1998 - the list goes on and on, culminating in the agency's wrong call on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction in 2002-3.

The CIA has a great reputation but a terrible record - it is inept. And yet the myth of the C.I.A. as an all-knowing, all-powerful spy agency persisted for years, not just in the minds of America's enemies but in the imagination of many American television-watchers and moviegoers
NOBODY, and I mean NOBODY, could be worse than Trump.
NO RNC information was ever divulged.  Wonder WHY???

I'd like very much to see evidence of increasing rate of participation in the job market, and preferably of a decrease in the rate of that increase AFTER some growth, before pronouncing the economy anywhere near full employment.

A nearby business can stand as an example of what's nice, but not good enough: a restaurant that was "Opening Soon!" for a couple of years finally opened. Something was encouraging enough to make that potential business with its jobs actual. But it isn't an example of anyone entirely changing intentions and increasing employment.

PEOTUS’ staff’s statement issued this afternoon attempts to pivot public attention toward whether or not voting machines were tampered with in this election. It’s a clever canard, but that’s not the crime that was committed here. The hacking and leaking of phished email begins with the crime of impersonation. It’s illegal in many states and or prosecuted under existing wire fraud statutes.
Russian operatives developed a full blown playbook around stolen email content that dates back to 2009 -when they conducted their first effective hack and leak operation against climate scientists that became known as Climategate. The victims still refer to it to this day as a smear campaign. Its effective because the public assumes that leaked email content is part of "transparency" when in fact stolen and manipulated information has zero integrity. It was obtained illegally.
PEOTUS’ team would have us believe that the election results were some sort of coronation, but in fact more people attended last month's Army/Navy game than provided the margin of victory in the three blue wall states. Bottom line, when you factor in Russian Operatives' role in manipulating the results this was certainly no electoral marvel. It was a squeaker (3rd narrowest margin in election history) with the difference being the assist from lawless operators based in the soviet republic.

It is time to for Mr. Trump to step aside and for Mr. Pence to be named
President. He is no better than Trump, except that Pence does not appear to be a con artist.

And one has to ask, if the situation were reversed, do you think that the Republicans would be following the law like the Democrats? No. Republicans will risk the very foundations of this republic to "win" political contests.

Consider the 2000 election and the Republican Supreme Court ordering the ballot recount to stop in Florida handing the election to Bush.

Consider the Senate's refusal to even hold hearings on the vacancy created by Justice Scalia's demise.

Consider the "fake" news attacks funded by the Koch brothers and their ilk.

Consider the letter by Director Comey eleven days or so before the election that was so damaging to Secretary Clinton.

Consider the housing crisis in 2007 and 2008 that President Obama had to clean up.

Consider the Republicans stated intention in 2009 to prevent Obama from getting anything done.

Consider the pending repeal of the ACA and the Republicans's refusal to discuss the issue in the House and Senate to improve it.

When Republicans win elections it means big business makes big money.

We no longer have a government of the people, by the people and for the people. It is time to bring it back. A good place to start is for Mr. Trump to resign. Hopefully the lawful articles of the Constitution can be properly applied and this lawlessness can be stopped.

I cannot understand how a democracy that supposedly adheres to the rule of law and a fair and honest election process cannot see there way to immediately having another presidential election after being informed by there very own intelligence group that the candidates did not have an equal playing field during the entire election process; is it a matter of cost ? if not what else could it be? the incoming Donald Trump is not yet president. there is still a very capable President in charge and I am certain he could continue on until people could be assured the incoming person would be the actual one who had gotten there in a fair and legitimate run election

Trump is a compulsive liar.
First he in his statement after he met with the Intelligence Chiefs he states that the Russian actions had no effect on the elections , the report did not state that in fact it concludes that they do not know if there was any effect.
So the question remains.
Suffice to say Putins hacking, passing on the results to Wikileaks had the clear objective of harming Ms Clinton as per the report. The fact Putin achieved his objective means that the probability that it influenced election is clear , no one can deny that the leaks harmed Clinton, reinforced negative perceptions.

The other lie ( there are so many) is that he promised to tell the American people what information he had , that no one else had on Tuesday and Wednesday of this week.So far nothing.

I hope the media keeps the pressure on him and his surrogates

Trump enters office with the lowest share (largest deficit) of the popular vote in 140 years.

Of course Putin's campaign influenced more than the 100,000 votes in the battleground states that provided the razor thin margin of victory in the Electoral College.

It takes a state actor to target disinformation in vulnerable states with precision.

Brexit was also a close vote based on disinformation.

Russia is attacking western democracy.

I would imagine that your average President makes 5 = 10 necessarily immediate decisions / day on deeply classified intelligence. None of the two - three weeks of tweeted nonsense and "prove it to me" disingenuous blather the Donald has issued.

Will he make the required quick decisions with due attention and proper regard to the daily intelligence? Will it be blended with the last Breitbart / Infowars assessments.

Good luck to us all. Fortunately, it looks like the building ridicule of Trump's foolishness will bring him quickly to the "this is no fun, and they're making me lose money" departure point within a month or two.

At any rate, before Russia's direct manipulation of him due to undisclosed conflicts or revelation of (likely) cached blackmail material occur.

Surely the intelligence community can probe into Trump's taxes and financial dealings to investigate his ties to Russian government and whether or not he benefits financially from Russian interests. He has given every reason to be suspicious of his refusal to denounce a foreign government hacking US government servers, and even publicly asked them to do so during his campaign.

If they are not motivated to investigate him for the sake of national security, and are not capable of finding the information necessary to draw a conclusion, then they are as incompetent as he claims they are. I surely don't want him to be proven right about that, because he is the epitome of all that is wrong with our country, and we need adult minds in the government to courageously protect us.
